M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
Why do schools teach literature? There is literally no benefit economically, so why do we waste taxpayer money on something that kids don't care about or remember nor add to our production?

Ironically, or possibly serendipitously, I was just taking a break from planning my literature class for next week when I saw this question. I can’t decide if I want to teach Of Mice and Men or The Little Prince next. It has to be something short, so I have time for my poetry unit at the end of the year. It was poor planning on my part that led to a two-week gap between novels for my class.

Anyway, the answers to your questions are, in no particular order:

  • You’re learning how to learn. That’s true for most things you’re taught in school. You won’t use those particular skills in the real world on a regular basis, but you WILL use the skills of learning new things, analyzing things, thinking critically, etc… Literature is just one of the vehicles schools use to get you to your actual destination: comprehension and critical thinking skills. Will you ever need to know the plot of Romeo and Juliet (or much math beyond fifth-grade level stuff, or the names of the moons of Saturn, etc…)? No. Those are just vehicles to get you to your destination.
  • There a term called “cultural capital.” While you may never need to know the plot to Romeo and Juliet, if you’re an American, the plot to that and many other forced-to-read-in-school pieces of literature are a kind of “capital” that adults have. Without it, you’re “culturally impoverished.”
  • Schools are there for more than just teaching students “useful in the real world” things. They also perform a lot of social services and, frankly, keep kids away from the “real world” during the day, so adults can go about their business in peace.
  • Schools are also there to teach students social skills.
  • Not everyone thinks literature is pointless. Some students actually enjoy it. That’s true for every single subject. Some students think it’s pointless, while others enjoy it.
  • Not all schools are taxpayer funded.
  • You’re not the first student to make this complaint.
  • You won’t be the last, either.

M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
Teachers in grade school and high school—-What were the parents of the troublemakers like?

I’m defining “troublemaker” here as “a student who frequently disrupted class, bullied other students, or generally lacked a level of self-control appropriate for their age.” I’ve always taught at private schools, where the bar for “troublemaker” is much lower than in a public school. Still, we did have them. Usually 3–4 per year.

Their parents were, in order of how common (some parents fit multiple of these categories):

  1. Absent. At least one of them had little to no contact with their child.
  2. Drug users/alcoholics.
  3. Recent immigrants with limited English abilities.
  4. Unwilling to monitor their children’s internet usage/basically abdicating one of the responsibilities of parenthood in the 21st century.
  5. Oblivious to how bad their child’s behavior was/thought what their child was doing was normal. (“Boys will be boys” is not an appropriate comment from a parent when told that their 11-year-old son asked a 14-year-old girl for nudes. But that was, in fact, the parent’s response when that happened where I taught a few years ago.)
  6. Made every single disciplinary issue about race/was convinced that their child was getting “picked on because of their race.”
  7. Noticeably younger than the other students’ parents.

The more of those categories a student’s parents fit into, the more likely that student is to have discipline issues in the classroom. At least, that’s been my experience.

M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
Is teaching a respected profession?

Openly? Less. It’s rare to her people criticize the teaching profession in public. They may criticize individual teachers, or teachers’ unions, but not the entire profession.

Teachers, as a group, are one of the groups of people that are mostly “off limits” to public criticism, especially from politicians, along with other groups like veterans, single mothers, etc… One of the quickest ways to end your political career is to badmouth teachers as a whole.

Outside of many urban areas, though, it’s actually a good political move to criticize teachers’ unions. That’s entirely different than criticizing the profession, though. Even here in Chicago, many public school teachers will tell you that their union has gone too far off the rails and doesn’t really represent them anymore.

Privately, though, a lot of people espouse less-than-ideal views of the teaching profession. For some, it’s considered a “fall back” profession for people who couldn’t do any better in life. Mostly because it’s considered an underpaid position for the level of education required (that’s not always true, though… in many major cities, teachers are paid very well), teachers tend to complain a lot for people who have a regular schedule with a lot of time off and aren’t doing manual labor, and teachers tend to get the blame for larger societal failures which just happen to manifest themselves in the classroom.

Teacher (2009–present)
Do you support building a high speed rail system in the US?

It depends on who’s building it.

If a for-profit company were building it, I’d support it. I trust that the company was working in their best interests and, most importantly, I wouldn’t be forced to support that company financially if I didn’t want to. I could choose to be their customer, or I could choose not to be. I could choose to be an investor, or I could choose not to be. The company would have financial accountability and the ability to go bankrupt if they mismanaged their funds.

If the government were building it, I wouldn’t support it. I’d expect the level of kickbacks and general corruption to increase with the level of government involved in the construction of the rail system. I’d expect everything to cost more than promised and deliver less than promised. Worst of all, I’d be forced to support it financially, indirectly, via taxes. I’d expect that the main beneficiaries of the project wouldn’t be people who used the rail system, but politicians and their well-connected friends who walked away with loads of taxpayer funds from the building of the project itself.

M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
Teachers of Quora, what are some examples of "gray area" situations you find yourself in as a teacher?

Grading student who can’t do grade-level work.

Sometimes, I can grade on “growth,” even if the student’s abilities haven’t grown to their grade level yet. If a seventh grader comes to me with a third-grade reading level, and makes it to a fourth-grade reading level by the end of the year, I can still give that student a good grade.

But some students show zero academic growth throughout the year. Some students hit their academic ceiling well below the grade levels I teach. These are students with special needs, both diagnosed and undiagnosed.

For example, a major part of the English curriculum I teach is essay writing. What type of essay depends on the year. Sixth graders get narrative essays, seventh graders get expository, and eighth graders get persuasive. No matter what type, though, the essays all have to be multiple paragraphs and grammatically correct.

Yet, year after year, there are some students with special needs who will turn in just one or two sentences each time I assign an essay. They simply cannot write more than that on their own. They hit their academic ceiling when it comes to writing well before getting to the grades I teach.

So what do I do? Keep giving them zeroes for those essays, which would make it impossible for them to pass my class? Grade them for their effort? Excuse them from the assignments?

How about re-teaching them how to write essays, for the 20th+ time? Which is actually another gray area:

How much time to dedicate to students on either end of the ability spectrum.

This is a major problem in middle school, since that’s where you’ll find the widest range of student abilities. In my classes this year, like every year, I have students who test at an 11th-grade level sitting next to students who test at a third-grade level. My planning time is very limited. Do I plan lessons to challenge the advanced students, which would frustrate the struggling students? Or do I plan lessons to help the struggling students, which would bore the advanced students?

In high school, those different levels of students would be in different classes completely.

Another gray area in teaching is when and how to punish students for violations that are actually their parents’ fault.

For example, some students are frequently tardy. After three tardies, a student is supposed to get a detention. But the students who are tardy the most are always dropped off by their parents. The students aren’t old enough to drive themselves and they don’t live close enough to just walk to school. They’re 100% reliant upon their parents to get them to school on time. If the parent keeps failing at that task, should we punish the student?

Uniform violations (it’s a Catholic school), students falling asleep in class, students swearing, bullying, or giving teachers attitude, or students saying inappropriate things (sexist, racist, homophobic, or even x-rated things) can also often be traced back to the parents. Do I punish the student who falls asleep in my class every single day when I know it’s because his parents keep him up late at night? What’s the appropriate punishment for the student who says something really sexist to a classmate, when that student was just repeating what his parents said and they had no idea it was inappropriate?

A major part of teaching is, basically, telling some students that the way their parents do things is wrong, both academically and behaviorally. But who are the students going to imitate? The teacher who they see for a few hours per day, 180 days per year, for a year or two? Or their parents with whom they’ve spent the other 95% of their lives?

That’s especially true in English and grammar when my students come from certain subcultures where nonstandard English and grammar is more common. There I am, a man from a different subculture, telling those students that the way the adults in their lives speak is, technically, incorrect and they’ll fail standardized tests if they answer with what they hear in the real world from the adults they respect and admire.

Teacher (2009–present)
Why do you think you have it made compared to others?

[There is no way to answer this without sounding really conceited, so here it goes:]

I pay attention.

I pay attention to the news. I pay attention to the stories I read online. I pay attention to the troubles of the people I know in real life.

And, from what I can tell from all of this attention paying, the world seems to be full of people working hard to achieve things that came relatively easy to me.

I was born and raised and still live in a first-world country. That, alone, means I “have it made” compared to the majority of humans in the world. People literally risk their lives every single day just trying to get to my country.

I found my life partner on the first try. I’ve been with the same woman for over half of my life now, and things just keep getting better between us. How many people do you know who’ve had their hearts broken or have given up finding “the one?” I’m in my 40s, and I’ve never experienced a break-up or a broken heart. Chances are, I never will.

We have three happy, healthy children. Ever met a parent of a child who isn’t so happy? Who isn’t so healthy? We rolled the dice three times, and came out winning each time.

My wife and I both have jobs we love. Mine is relatively low-stress, too. Lots of time off for me. In fact, this is day #8 of a 9-day break for me. I’m looking forward to going back to work on Monday. It will be an easy six weeks, then I’ll have eight weeks off. My wife doesn’t get nearly as much time off as I do, but she does get to work from home full time. And she gets a lot of accolades in her field. And she gets very, very well compensated for the work that she does.

Stable employment doing something you love and being well compensated for it? Do you know someone who wishes they had that in their life right now? My wife and I have both had it for over a decade and, trust me… it’s very nice. I recommend it.

Don’t even get me started on my dog. She’s adorable and loyal and better than your dog.

Do you know someone who struggles with depression or anxiety? Or maybe someone who is just sad a lot of the time? I know a lot of people like that, too. I can’t really relate to them, though. Happiness is my default state. It has been since 1992. If you added the total time I’ve been unhappy since then, it would total maybe two weeks.

Maybe you know someone who drinks or does drugs? Maybe they can’t stop, and it’s having a negative impact on their lives? I know some people like that. My sister died of a drug overdose, actually. But me? I can’t stand the taste of alcohol. I don’t drink. I’ve never done drugs. I did smoke for a few years there when I was a teen. So there’s that. Once I decided to quit when I was 20 years old, it was easy for me to do. I just quit cold turkey, and never looked back.

Perhaps you know people who are having an existential crisis? Struggling with meaning in their lives? Losing faith in their religion, perhaps? Wondering what the point is of everything? I know people like that. I’m not one of them, though. I found my religion (Catholicism) when I was 21 years old, and haven’t really questioned it since. It’s comforting, knowing what to expect when I die, and knowing the “bigger picture” for everything. No existential crises for me.

I honestly feel like, if you could read everyone’s minds and figure out what they were all yearning for in life, about 95% of humanity would be yearning for something I already have. That’s why I feel I’ve “made it compared to others.”

Teacher (2009–present)
Do people with kids prefer suburbs than downtown?

It depends on the parents, of course.

There are also more than just two options. There are the parts of the city between downtown and the suburbs, and there are small towns, rural areas, etc…

On an anecdotal note, There are a lot of affluent families with children in my social circle. These are people who could easily afford to live in downtown Chicago with their children.

Only one of the families in my social circle actually tried it, though. They lived in a high-rise near Soldier Field:

In that cluster of high-rises to the left, just north of the stadium.

They thought it would be cool to raise their kids near Grant Park (the big park in the picture) and the Field Museum (big white building by the stadium) aquarium (white round building next to the water), planetarium (not in the picture), and everything else downtown Chicago has to offer.

They hated it. They lived there fewer than two years before moving to the suburbs.

According to them, they rarely did those “downtown living” sorts of things, and wanted more personal space (bigger house and a yard of their own). If they wanted to do those downtown things in the future, they’d just commute in and, if needed, get a hotel for the night.

The trend among most people in my social circle has been:

  • Be raised in the suburbs or a non-crowded part of the city.
  • Move to a trendy/crowded part of the city, close to downtown. In Chicago, Lincoln Park or Wicker Park are popular for young, single people.
  • Find a life partner, get married, begin to think about having children.
  • Say you’ll never leave the city… complain about your own suburban upbringing.
  • Have child.
  • Move to suburbs.
  • Buy SUV.
  • Begin shopping at Costco a lot.
  • If you’re a guy, get into either smoking your own meats, or woodworking. (I picked woodworking.)
  • If you’re a woman, get into interior decorating or the local craft beer scene. (My wife picked interior decorating.)
  • Raise your children in the same suburban manner you hated when you were aged 16–24ish.
  • Watch the cycle repeat.

M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
Teachers, have you ever found students trying to hide that they're smart?

This happens A LOT at the middle school level. Usually sometime around the middle of their 7th grade year, a lot of the smartest, most outspoken students who participate the most in class discussions and are generally a pleasure to teach… suddenly go silent. They begin to act disinterested. Their test scores remain high, but it’s like their open enthusiasm for learning just leaves them.

Peer pressure is usually the culprit. Kids at that age want nothing more than to fit in with their classmates. That’s also when a lot of body image issues begin to take hold. Students who’d been overweight for years without a care in the world suddenly get really, really self-conscious about it.

Very few 13-year-old students are comfortable “sticking out” in the classroom. For smart students who love school and love participating in lessons, part of no longer “sticking out” is shutting up and acting like you don’t care about school, because so many of your classmates… particularly the “cool kids…” are acting that way.

Most of them grow out of it eventually. By about age 16 or so, they get more comfortable with who they really are, and quit caring so much about what their classmates think about them.

Teacher (2009–present)
Why are cities building so many luxury apartments but hardly any affordable housing?

Cities don’t really build apartment buildings. Developers do that. Unlike city governments, developers are for-profit entities. If they’re building one type of thing, and not building another type of thing, it’s because there’s more money to be made with the first type of thing.

John AllenLike the other guy commented, sounds good on paper, but isn’t so in practice. An annoying cost component of apartment buildings is property management. With affordable housing, you’re making less $ per unit, and you’ll have many more people to keep track of. On top of that, it’s no secret that on average, residents of affordable housing units may pose more problematic than residents of high-end units. As a property manager, think about dealing with these two types of residents. For the wealthier residents, they may be arrogant and snobbish, but your building would require few units to be profitable and having issues with payment for rent is less likely. Even if you come across some rich person who trashes the place, you’re more likely to be able to get them to cover damages and move on. Also less likely to have issues among residents in terms of disputes and etc. On the flip side, imagine you’re running a building with many more units in an affordable housing building. You have way more people to keep track of. These people aren’t swimming in money (which means enforcing fines for broken rules is more difficult). If they trash the place, you have to go after them to cover damages, and they may give you some story about how they’re low on money or something (all the while, you still need to stay on top of everything day to day for everyone else). You’re also more likely to come across criminality, such as drug abuse or potentially cases of violence. Also, with all these people, it’s all the more likely the fire alarm is set off or there’s a problem with odor in the building, and etc. For the property management team itself, you’ll need more people to keep track of everything (unless you don’t care and just have fewer people and awful service), which means you’ll want to spend less per employee. However, the fact that it’s an affordable housing unit means that fewer people would want to work there, and you may even lose out on most women being willing to work there if they don’t feel safe. Meanwhile, although workers may get annoyed by snobby residents of a high-end building, they would feel much safer and you could opt to have fewer employees, giving you the ability to pay more to attract better quality people to keep residents happy.

Teacher (2009–present)
How can we lower the cost of living in large cities, such as San Francisco, L.A, and New York?

The price of something rises to the point where enough people are willing to pay for it for the sellers to stay in business. You know, supply and demand and all. For the price of something to go down, one of two things has to happen:

  1. The supply of that thing increases.
  2. The demand for that thing decreases.

So, either allow builders in cities it build larger buildings with more housing units in them, or discourage people from moving to the cities.

I happen to live in a single-family home in an affluent part of a major American city. I know that, if the city allowed #1 in this neighborhood, it would bring down housing prices in two ways. If they allowed a developer to build a huge apartment or condo building in the neighborhood, it would increase the supply of available housing here, but also decrease the demand for the single-family homes in the area. The demand is high in this neighborhood specifically because it’s all single-family homes. There’s always plenty of street parking, the neighborhood is quiet at night, kids can play outside in safety, etc… It feels like a suburb because the city doesn’t allow developers to pack more units into the area.

Every time a developer even floats the idea of building anything more than a three-unit building near here, people begin protesting against it. No one who doesn’t already live in a densely-packed neighborhood wants to live in one.

For younger people still searching for their first home, this probably seems unfair. It’s like there was a game of musical chairs for nice, affordable houses in the city, and the music stopped about 10 years ago. Now people in those houses aren’t going to add more chairs to the game, or give up their chairs without a significant profit.

Last fall, I helped clean out the house of one of my in-laws who’d passed away. She’d been a widow for several years and her house was in a state of disrepair. It was, though, a single-family house within the city limits of Chicago, in a neighborhood full of other single-family homes. After getting the house “broom clean,” despite all of the work it needed (honestly, it may even just be a total teardown), they listed it for $250k. They had OVER 80 offers on the first day, all with no showings whatsoever. Most were all-cash offers from investors. They ended up selling it for well over the asking price, still sight unseen, all in cash.

That’s what young couples are up against these days… investors buying up houses to flip them or rent them.

And, honestly, it’s an idea my wife and I have batted around a few times too: buying a second house and renting it out. Possibly even renting it to our own daughter. In three or four years, we’ll be able to be one of those all-cash buyers, right around the time our oldest should be looking to buy a house and start a family. We could charge her rent, but also be comfortable knowing that she’d take care of the place.

Teacher (2009–present)
What's something you look back on now that you thought was a big deal in high school or college but doesn't matter anymore?

All things related to pop culture, including: television shows, movies, music, sports, celebrities, and fashion.

When I was a student, things like new albums from your favorite musicians, new movies in your favorite genres, etc… were big news. We waited in line to get a copy or see the movie the day it came out. If you missed a certain movie or show or game, you were left out of the conversations for days or weeks afterwards. Being “in the know” about pop culture was a prerequisite to having a social life.

Once I began working full time at age 19, and I had real-world responsibilities, my interest in and concern for pop culture began to wane. By the time I was 30 and had a career, two kids, and a home to maintain, I’d pretty much tuned out of pop culture altogether. That’s why I still think of Lady Gaga and Taylor Swift as “new” artists, since they were new right around the time I quit caring about new music.

I’ve been half-assed keeping up with the MCU. I did enjoy WandaVision. I have yet to see all of Endgame. It’s on my “I’ll get to it when I get to it” list. But these things aren’t really important to me. They’re just things I watch when I’m super bored and don’t feel like reading or writing.

I haven’t watched a full football game in over a decade now. I just don’t have three hours in a row to dedicate to that anymore. My wife and I try to watch some of the Super Bowl every year, but we usually only get about an hour’s worth before we’re bored or have something in the real world that needs our attention.

I did see the Super Bowl halftime show this year. I honestly had no idea who that singer was. I recognized one of the songs, though: “Blinding Lights.” It wasn’t until I heard it on the news the next day that I learned that the singer’s name is “The Weeknd.”

My father was the same way when I was in high school and more “into” pop culture. He had no idea who half of the musicians were that I liked… the most popular musicians of the day… nor did he really care. He had more important things to worry about every day.

Wed
Teacher (2009–present)
As a parent over the age of 35 years old with children still in school, what do you notice between how school is now compared to when you were a student?

I have the added benefit of not just being a parent, but a teacher, so I see some behind-the-scenes things that other parents don’t get to see, and that I didn’t notice when I was a student.

My children are 7, 10, and 21.

There are two things that come to mind immediately when I think about how different their education is than mine was at their age.

The first is the obvious one: technology. When I was a student, each school had a computer lab, and teachers would sign up their classes to use the lab once or twice per week. We mostly used them to play games. Where In The World Is Carmen San Diego was popular back then. As was Oregon Trail.

Nowadays, though, computers and iPads are much more prevalent in every part of my children’s (and students’) curriculum. Since I began teaching 12 years ago, my students have always had 1:1 tech. My oldest daughter went 1:1 tech when she was in high school. My younger two children will go 1:1 with tech when they’re in sixth grade. All of my children, including my seven year old, know how to use email and Google Docs and Google Classroom.

The second obvious change has been with the cultural diversity of the curriculum. When I was a student, our textbooks had a smattering of non-American-sounding names or stories by women or non-white men. But nowadays, the pendulum has swung to the total opposite direction. Only about 25% of the names the textbooks use in their examples these days are names of people I know in the real world. About 10% of the names are names I’ve never even heard before and I’m not sure if I’m pronouncing correctly.

When I was a kid, I’d get things like this in my textbooks:

“John had ten apples. He gave three to Sally. How many apples does John have left?”

My youngest daughter’s math book has sentences like this in it:

“Phuoc bought 10 persimmons. He gave 7 to Abayomi. How many persimmons does Phuoc have left?”

The majority of stories in the reading anthologies are by women now. And just under half of the stories are from non-Western cultures.

It’s easy to see this shift in the “Oral Traditions” unit I teach. When I was a student, it was pretty much a lot of Greek mythology, a little Norse mythology, and some American tall tales. Now, it’s a little Greek mythology, Chinese mythology, African folklore, Mexican tall tales, Native American mythology.

Like Samantha Kelly said in her answer, the curriculum has expanded in breadth, but not depth. There are only so many hours in the school day, and in the effort to be more inclusive of other cultures (breadth), the depth of the curriculum had to be cut. Instead of two dozen different Greek myths, the students get four or five of them, and four or five myths from various other cultures.

Wed
Teacher (2009–present)
I am starting middle school this September. Do you have any advice?

Middle school teacher here.

Here is the best advice for middle school, at least academically:

  1. Get a planner.
  2. Use it.

Virtually all of my “C” or lower students could raise their grade by a letter if they’d just turn in their work on time, or turn it in at all. My students are all issued planners every year. Half of them never use it. That’s the same half that underperforms academically.

It’s really easy. At the end of each class, take 30 seconds to write down that class’s homework in your planner. If you have no homework for that class, write “none,” so you know you aren’t forgetting it, but that there was none.

Then, when you get home, open your planner and see what needs to be done. Then do it.

This falls under something adults call “executive functioning skills.” But you don’t need to know all of that. Just get a planner and use it, and things will be much easier for you.

Teacher (2009–present)
What is something people have commented about you with negative intentions but you take as a compliment?

I first heard it on the Thom Hartmann Show (progressive talk radio) in 2009, and since then I’ve heard or seen variations of it repeated on other progressive/liberal shows or from random people online. Variations of:

“Christianity is a bronze-age religion.”

Sometimes they leave out “Christianity” and just say “you worship a bronze-age God.” Or they change the era in an attempt to connote “ignorant.” “You have a medieval set of morals based on an even older concept of a deity.”

The basic idea behind all of those are the same: To believe in something that people in the past also believed in is somehow based on ignorance.

Actually, I find it very comforting to believe in something that people have been believing in for thousands of years. There is no “take” on this belief that I can have that hasn’t already been had by millions of people. It’s been considered, pondered over, discussed, etc… for thousands of years, and yet the core beliefs are all still the same.

Me: [Has question or concern about my faith.]

Me: [Has two thousand years’ worth of other people’s thoughts about the same questions and concerns to fall back on.]

Honestly, as the years of my own life roll on, and my experiences with “new” thoughts and beliefs accumulate, I realize that maybe the generations before me weren’t as ignorant as I thought they were when I was a teen and an active member in all things “new.” There’s a good reason why so many older people cringe at the new trends of the generations after them. There’s also a good reason why so many people become more conservative and nostalgic for older things as they themselves get older. As you mature, you realize that the things you rejected from previous generations made more sense than you gave them credit for. You were just too young to realize it when you rejected them.

April 5
Teacher (2009–present)
Do American schools also force their students (5th to 9th) to participate in drama, music, dance, and sports like they do in my country? What if someone refuses music?

American schools are decentralized, so each school will offer different classes. Around here, though, it usually goes like this:

Drama is a class of its own in high school (grades 9–12), but it’s an elective. Students choose to take it. There is also usually a drama unit as part of English classes, but there’s little to no acting involved with that. It’s just reading and studying plays as literature.

Music is a once-per-week class in middle school (grades 6–8) and elementary school (grades K-5). It’s mandatory and exists not only to teach the students about music, but to give the regular teachers a break. In high school, classes like band or chorus are electives for students who want to take them.

Dance is an elective in high school, and a unit in gym class in middle and elementary school. Gym class, like music class, exists not only to give the students a chance to learn the subject, but also to give the regular teachers a break.

“Sports” isn’t a class. There’s “gym,” also known as “physical education” or “P.E.”. That’s mandatory in grades K-9 usually. If you play sports in high school, you may also take advanced P.E. classes or weight training. Those are all electives for most people, but your coach may require it for members of a team.

Teacher (2009–present)
Why is the conservative boogeyman so often a poor person who tries to claim a benefit they don't "deserve"?

Because so many of us know people like that.

We know people who COULD get off of government assistance, if they wanted to, but they chose to stay on it because it’s easier for them.

We know people who game the system; people who under-report what they get paid in cash, so that they don’t get taxed on it and still qualify for benefits.

We know people who had every opportunity to make a better, government assistance-free life for themselves, but instead took the lazy, often hedonistic path.

We know people who factored in government assistance before intentionally having children. They didn’t see the assistance as an emergency fund… they saw it as regular income.

We know people who aren’t in this country legally, yet are getting government benefits for which we, the legal citizens, don’t qualify.

It’s not just about the money would could save in our taxes. We know that taxes will never go down, and that the military takes a huge chunk of tax revenue. It’s the principle of it all. The idea that we’re out here, busting our asses every day, playing by the rules, and making good choices, all while being forced (with literally the threat of prison time for tax evasion) to support other who aren’t working as hard as we are, aren’t playing by the rules, aren’t making good choices, etc…

In my 20+ years of adulthood I’ve known at least 30 perfectly capable adults who were on some form of government assistance for non-emergency reasons. The most common were people who worked part-time and were offered full-time positions, but didn’t take it because they’d “make too much” to qualify for government benefits. The second most common were people who got paid in cash and never reported it.

I’d bet that more than half of the people I’ve ever known on government assistance could have gotten off of it if they wanted to.

Potheads/meth addicts are another group. The fully-capable adult who sits around smoking pot all day while collecting welfare isn’t some conservative boogeyman for many of us. In my case, it’s my cousin and my sister and some of her druggie friends (back when she was alive). They knew the right person at the Social Security office to help them get a disability claim through, so they didn’t have to work full-time like the rest of us.

The game the system and brag about it.

And guys like me… we think about that a lot in the mornings, as we’re getting ready for another day at work, waking up early, fighting traffic, putting in our time, fighting traffic to get home, and repeating it all the next day.

It doesn’t take long for one’s thoughts to go from “I’m doing my part to help the downtrodden” to “wait a minute… I’m the shmuck here…”.

April 4
M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
How does the teacher pick the pupil they are going to use as an example to the class?

I teach English at the middle school level. About once per week, my students have some sort of writing prompt or more formal essay to do. I like to project some of those essays for the entire class to see, so we can read and edit it together, so we can all learn from each other. Or, if it was a narrative prompt, I like to have students read in front of the class what they wrote. That way they can practice their public speaking. Plus, most of them like to share what they wrote.

But there’s never enough time to do that for everyone’s essays or narratives. So how do I decide which ones get projected or shared? I have two methods:

  1. The fish bowl. Every student’s name is on a ping pong ball in a fish bowl. I reach in a grab a ping pong ball, NBA draft lottery style, and the person who is picked can either accept or pass.
  2. The random number. I shuffle all of the papers and stack them neatly. Then I ask a student to “give me a number between one and five.” I go through the papers until I get to the number they called, calling all of the names along the way. “Mark picked #4. That’s not Julia, not John, not Amy, yes Timmy! You’re the winner!”

The middle school crowd enjoys these methods. It makes a routine classroom task a little more fun. It also helps that I’ve always worked at small, private schools where the students have all known each other for years and generally like each other.

If you mean “make an example of” in a negative way, that’s easy: I do it with the first student who needs to have their behavior corrected. That’s the best way to do it… to establish alpha-dog status with the preteens… as early in the year and as publicly as possible.

Fortunately for me, the schools here in Chicago are for grades K-8. There are few stand-alone middle schools. That means that my coworkers have all had the students before and can warn me which ones to look out for before they even get into my class. In fact, the teachers have meetings over the summer specifically to discuss each student’s strengths and weaknesses, both academically and behaviorally.

So, on the first day of school, once that first student does something against the rules, I give them a warning. If they do it again, they get a detention, which is the harshest punishment I can give them. Anything worse than that and the principal has to get involved. Most of the time, that warning and detention go to a student for talking while I’m trying to teach. Usually they’re cracking jokes and trying to be the class clown. Getting a detention on the first day of school is a wake-up call for them.

And it works. Of all of my coworkers, I always have the fewest discipline problems with my students, and a lot of it has to do with making an example of the first student on the first day of a new school year.

April 3
Teacher (2009–present)
What is unfair in your profession?

I’m a middle school teacher. There are A LOT of unfair things to choose from the field of education.

But if I had to narrow it down to the single most unfair thing, it would be how a small minority of students with behavior issues can set the pace for everyone else in the class. If you happen to go to a smaller school and those same students are always in your class, it’s possible that your own education can be stunted after multiple years of your teachers having to spend a disproportionate amount of time and energy just trying to control a few students in the classroom.

I usually teach multiple classes of the same grade and subject, but I can’t do the same lessons with the different classes, because I have to account for the students with discipline issues in each class. So “class A” might get a fun group project while I wander around the room, checking in with each group, while “class B” gets worksheets, because Timmy is in “class B,” and he simply cannot handle any sort of freedom in the classroom.

I say, “get with your groups and work on this project,” and Timmy hears, “free time to wander the room and pick on people.”

So, for the entire year, “class B’s” lessons are toned down to Timmy’s level of self control. The other 20–25 students in his class, who’ve done nothing wrong, have their education altered and possibly stunted because of Timmy.

And, for various reasons, mostly involving lawyers, discrimination laws and lawsuits, progressive educational consultants and politicians who wish to appeal to them for some reason, and a lack of resources, we can’t just kick the Timmys of the world out of the classroom anymore.

One of the worst parts about being a middle school teacher is seeing the love of learning slowly die in advanced students as they pull away from their classmates academically, self-control-wise, and maturity-wise, and they sit there, day after day, bored out of their minds as their teacher has to spend all of their time and effort on students like Timmy.

I’ll bet that for most of you reading this, especially if you are under the age of 45 and a product of American schools, can remember a small handful of your former classmates who seemed to dominate the entire class with their behavior issues. You may have been annoyed by it or even found it entertaining back then, but imagine how much more your teacher could have done with you if they didn’t have to waste so much time trying to teach the unteachable or those that didn’t want to be taught? Would you have been a happier student? Done better on your SATs or ACTs? Maybe gotten some academic scholarships or into a better college? Could your entire life be on a better track now if not for a handful of classmates back when you were in school?

1.1K views ·

Called it. The morning they announced the suggested edits change, and the official reason for it, I posted that the official reason was just a cover, and that it was because trolls were using edit suggestions to harass people.
Questions for Quora Leadership
·
March 31
Admin · Answered by
Adam D'Angelo
The official reasons advanced for the suppression of the Suggested Edits feature seem fabulous to many of us in this place. What would it take to bring it back?

First, you are right that the official reasons given for removing the feature were wrong. An internal process broke down that should have caught this and we have made some changes so that this kind of communications failure won’t happen again. Since that breakdown, I actually have been personally signing off on all of these communications about product changes to prevent this going forward.

We removed suggest edits primarily because it made development on our editors extremely complicated. We needed to make sure every feature in and around each of our editors would interact properly with suggest edits, and we need to maintain editor parity across iOS, Android, mobile web, and desktop web, so any complexity in this system gets magnified. Suggest edits was also a vector for harassment and spam, and users would sometimes get confused and accidentally accept a suggestion that they didn’t mean to accept.

The problem with having a product that is too complicated is that we can’t maintain the level of product quality that we want, and we can’t evolve our product over time - it means a high level of bugs and other issues, and it means less of our effort can go to making the product better so that more people can share their knowledge. With all that said, I know that a lot of people liked this feature and I hope we can bring it back someday when we have more resources to invest in this area.

Teacher (2009–present)
What’s refreshing about being your age?

I am 40.

The most refreshing things about being my age are attainment, stability, and safety.

Back in my early 20s, I lived alone and worked every odd job I could get to earn $15 here or $20 there, because it made a big difference in my life. I had a full-time job taking care of a disabled teen in a very affluent suburb of Chicago, but I’d sometimes work side-jobs doing the same thing for other disabled teens whose parents knew me through my primary client. A big, strong, college student who had no qualms about taking care of the personal hygiene needs for teenage boys who couldn’t take care of them themselves was a hot commodity back then. My services were in demand, particularly on weekend nights when the teen’s parents wanted to go on a date.

I remember going to the houses of the people I worked for and being both jealous and sad. These people were all affluent professionals who were paying me out of their own pockets because it wasn’t that much to them. They had huge houses and beautiful wives and happy children and just amazing lives… the types of lives that I never thought I’d have. I couldn’t see past paying the rent on my studio apartment every month to even think about owning a nice house in a nice neighborhood with a beautiful wife and happy, healthy children and a career I actually enjoyed.

But now I’m there. I am living the type of life that made me jealous of other guys when I saw them living it 20 years ago. Attainment. It’s a great thing.

And, as long as I don’t screw it up with some really bad choices, or encounter some really bad luck, the odds are that I will keep this enviable life for the rest of my life. Stability and safety. They’re also really great things.

Some people… particularly younger people… cringe at the thought of how boring a life like mine must be. Every day is pretty much the same, and has been for several years now. The last major change in my life happened four years ago when we got our dog.

Yep, four consecutive years of the same routine almost every day. It’s wonderful! I love it. I love it the way only a man in his 40s who has everything he ever wanted could love it.

We even vacation at the same beach every year. After we did it for five years in a row, I casually suggested that we try a different vacation spot one year. My wife didn’t like that idea. Honestly, I didn’t like it either. I just thought she may be getting bored of the same beach. But she wasn’t. Neither was I. We have the time and money to take our family anywhere we want to in the U.S. for one full week each summer, and we just want to go to the same beach each time. It’s comforting. It’s stable. It’s safe.

We stick with what we know and what we like, and we’re as happy as we can be.

So much of life in your teens and 20s is like running an obstacle course. Gotta find the right life partner, find the right career, figure out where you want to live, pray that your children are healthy, etc…

Being 40 is like making it through the obstacle course and into the “light jog to the end” part of your life. You can calm down a little and enjoy the view and, as long as you don’t totally stop moving forward, you’ll get to the finish line sooner or later.

What are some weird thoughts you have?

“I could totally build my own casket.”

I think this a lot when I’m doing some woodworking/making things for the house. Pretty much everything I make is just a version of a box (radiator covers, flower boxes, raised gardens, bookshelves, etc…). A casket wouldn’t be too difficult for me, especially if it didn’t need to have a hinged lid.

“If I were a sniper, I could probably hit that person from here.”

I think this sometimes when I look out of my classroom window, which is on the top floor of the school.

“Whatever happened to [things I used to own but gave away or traded, like cars.]”

I sometimes wonder if the old ’97 Ford Taurus that I had when I met my wife is still out there being driven by someone, or has been scrapped by now. We traded it in for a new car in 2008.

I also like to mentally:

  • Calculate how old I am, down to the day, and then do the same for my father or grandfather, and compare what we were doing on the same exact day of our lives.
  • Calculate the number of days I’ve outlived my older sister.
  • Go over scenarios of what I’d do if I were on the run from the law for some reason. Step one: get rid of cell phone. Step two: get as much cash as possible. Step three: change license plates on car.

I also like to research the stars of music videos from the ’90s that I used to like. Not the actual singers or bands, but the random actors who were tapped to be in the music videos. The internet is very helpful for this. I can tell I’m not the only one who Googles things like “who is the girl from the Duran Duran “Come Undone” music video?” Her name was Lamya and she died of a heart attack at age 45.

Edit: Apparently the internet lied to me. That woman’s name was Tessa Niles, and she’s still alive.

Teacher (2009–present)
What made you upset today?

Technically, this happened yesterday, but this is my first chance to write about it.

I took the day off of work yesterday to run some errands with my wife. These errands were related to some home improvement projects we’re in the middle of, and the places we needed to visit were only open on weekdays. We were tired of waiting for a time when we both had the day off, so we both just took a personal day to get it all done.

(Side note: it takes me about two hours to plan everything for my substitute when I have the day off. Since I normally only teach six hours per day, I really, really hate taking days off. It’s just a pain and everything is much easier if I’m just there, doing it myself.)

One of the things we needed to do was visit a custom stone fabricator to get some stone for the facing of our new fireplace. I, personally, don’t know anything about stone. My wife, though, is some sort of stone aficionado. That meant we had to travel to multiple places to get just the right black soapstone with white stripes in it. Every place we went… all of the hundreds of stone slabs we looked at, in person and online… all seemed perfectly fine to me. But not to her. To her, “which fireplace stone” is a decision somewhere between “which god to pray to” and “how many children to have” on the important-decision-o-meter. For me, it’s somewhere between “what to have for breakfast” and “could I wear these pants again without washing them?”

But I digress…

One of the places we had to go to look at pieces of stone (remnants, to be exact… we didn’t need much) was in a part of Chicago that I used to drive through on a regular basis 20 years ago when I was in college. It was in-between my apartment and the college, plus I had a friend who lived in that neighborhood.

Back then, there were one or two homeless people here or there in that neighborhood. Maybe 15, total, if you really looked for them.

But now? I was truly shocked by all of the homeless encampments we saw. There were clusters of tents, 10–20 in a cluster, in at least five different places in that neighborhood. One of them was along the back of the building we had to go into. We saw it as we drove around the building, looking for parking.

None of the people in the encampments were actively begging for money or anything. It was the middle of the day, and the ones we could see were just hanging around, talking to each other. If not for the fact that they were dirty and in the middle of viaducts or parks or sidewalks and clearly living in the tents they were standing next to, you may have thought that these were just some friends out doing some camping before returning home.

At first, I felt a little guilty. There I was, taking a day off of work to go shopping for an expensive way to finish an upgrade to my home, and all around me were people for whom what I was about to spend on a piece of stone would make a major difference in their life.

But then I thought about it more, and I came to the conclusion I always come to in these situations: the government (in this case, the city of Chicago) already has enough money to solve this problem, if they spent their money wisely. It’s not me who’s the problem… it’s the corrupt politicians. Chicago has some of the highest sales and property taxes in the country. I already pay more than enough to help all of the homeless people I saw that day. Not to mention what I donate to charities. If the money I’m already paying isn’t making a difference, I don’t see how giving (or having taken via taxes) more of money would do anything besides make me poorer.

In fact, by spending money on home improvements, I’d argue that I was doing MORE to help the economy and those on the bottom rungs of the socio-economic ladder than most others are doing. I was keeping the wheels of the economy humming to the best of my abilities. The money I was spending on home improvements was going into the pockets of local working-class people. The worst thing that could happen for the bottom rungs of the socio-economic ladder in Chicago would be for families like mine to give up and move elsewhere. In fact, that’s one of the main reasons things are so bad in the city now… families like mine… upper-middle class, married couples with school-aged children… started fleeing to the suburbs in the 1950s.

Still, it’s a hopeless feeling. It’s a feeling like my adoptive hometown… Chicago… is in a Detroit-like downward spiral, and the only people who can stop it… the politicians… are doing the exact opposite things they should be doing. What they’re doing is making things worse, not better.

Teacher (2009–present)
What is the best way to join the upper class?

If we’re talking about “class” in terms of “income levels,” here’s what you need in the US to be “upper class.” Or, at least, “upper-income range:”

According to that chart, most of the families I know would be considered “upper income range.” Here’s how most of them did it:

  • Graduated from college with a useful degree.
  • Married someone else who graduated from college with a useful degree.
  • Got a job with a major company by the time they were 25, and stuck with that job even during the crappy early years. OR…
  • Started their own business that sold things to other businesses or provided services to wealthy individuals.
  • Avoided doing hard drugs.
  • Waited until they were in a committed relationship before having children.

Additionally, many of them made their lives much easier by:

  • Living near adult relatives (their own parents, their adult siblings) who could help with childcare and other things.
  • Going into a field that requires some sort of state license (law, medical, even teaching) that prevents their incomes from being undercut by unlicensed competition.
  • Using alcohol and/or smoking weed in moderation or not at all.
  • Living a modest lifestyle well below their means, and putting as much as possible into savings and investments every month.
  • Working for the government.

All of these couples hit their “upper-income range” stride in their mid-to-late 30s. They would all tell you that there were some pretty lean years before that, which makes them much more appreciative and careful with their money when it finally came rolling in in higher numbers than it was rolling out.

Teacher (2009–present)
What is effortless for you, but not for most people you know?

Reaching things on high shelves, cleaning ceiling fans, and generally anything that those of us in the top 1% of height for all humans get to enjoy that you other 99% shorties don’t.

Being tall (and wide) as a teacher also makes it much easier for me to get and keep a class’s attention. It also helps that I am a guy. My coworkers are usually all average-sized or smaller women whose primary attention-getting tactic from the students is to raise their voices. Me? I just stare at the students until they quiet down. You can’t really ignore a guy like me staring at you. Every now and then I have to slap my desk to make a really loud attention-getting noise, if the students need to be “snapped out of” whatever they were doing and back to focusing on the lesson.

As far as things that are mentally easy for me compared to others, relaxing is the first thing that comes to mind. Most adults I know struggle to “unwind” or “destress” or “relax” or “clear their mind” or however they want to put it. Me? Relaxed is my normal state. Work doesn’t stress me out at all anymore. Neither do my children. The things that cause most adults I know the most stress are actually enjoyable to me. I like having a lot of things to do every day. I take it as a sign that I’m living a good life.

I can thank my experiences in my early 20s for my relaxed attitude towards things that stress out other people now. Back then, I was struggling to pay my bills, worked with disabled teens, and spent most of my free time alone in my studio apartment. I dreamed about the type of life I’m living now… financially secure with a job I enjoy, raising my family in a nice house, and I even have a loyal dog. Even if the kids need things from me or the house takes a lot of effort to keep clean and running smoothly or the dog requires a lot of my attention… I don’t mind. This is the life I wanted, and I feel blessed to have it.

I’m going to miss all of these “stressors” one day. That’s what my mother tells me every time I talk to her. She’s a widow now, living along, with nothing but time to do whatever she wants to all day, every day. And what does she want to do? Go back and enjoy more time being stressed out with everything she had to do for work and her family when she was my age.

Matthew Bates

March 26
M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
How do teachers handle students who are actually smart but poor in performance/grades?

We get this a lot at the middle school level due to the wide range of student abilities all within the same class at the same time. The “smart” students begin to self-identify as such and their fledgling teenage rebellion begins to manifest itself with variations of: “I know this… why do I have to prove to you that I know it? I’m the smartest kid in this class, can’t you tell? I’m not going to jump through the hoops (classwork) just to prove to you what we both already know… that I’m a genius.”

It’s a combination of arrogance, being overly-praised for average efforts their entire life, and puberty-induced desires for rebellion and independence.

I just give them the grade that they earn and move on with my life.

If, for example, a student knows how to use semicolons to separate independent clauses, but doesn’t do the classwork I assign to prove that they know it, I give the student a “0” for that lesson, which is what they earned with their refusal to do the work, and then I move on.

They usually don’t care. Their parents usually don’t care, either… particularly once the student has already been accepted into a high school. So I adjust my level of concern to match theirs.

Sometimes, though, they do care. They’re shocked that I’d “fail them” for not doing something, when they considered that something as just busy work. I usually hit them with a bit of fatherly advice that will help them going forward in high school:

“It’s not about being smart. It’s about following directions. You spend more time trying to explain why you’re too smart to do the work than you would have spent if you just did the work. If you’re so smart, you should fly through these assignments, get a good grade, and move on with your life. Instead, you get a low grade and spend days and weeks trying to convince your parents and me that your grades don’t reflect how smart you really are. Your attempts to avoid work that you think is beneath you are just making your life more difficult. There’s nothing smart about that.”

Sometimes that works. Sometimes it doesn’t.

I do know, however, that a lot of really “smart” middle schoolers develop really bad attitudes towards classwork and studying, and it comes back to bite them in high school, when their “smart” is just “average” for the level of class they’re in. It’s better that they learn hard lessons before they get there.

Teacher (2009–present)
What has been your experience with the American Dream?

I’m living it every day. I have been for about 15 years now, give or take.

Everyone’s “American Dream” is different, but for most, it’s something like:

  • Work hard and enjoy the fruits of your own labor.
  • Achieve a better life than your parents.
  • Make it possible for your children to achieve a better life than you.

I was the first in my family to graduate college. I went on to graduate school even. I have a better career than my father had. Well, at least an easier and cleaner one. I’m a teacher; he was a machinist. We both got married in our 20s to the mother of our children, and stayed married to our wives our entire lives. Well, obviously I’m still alive, but my wife and I are as happy as we can be together.

I have three happy, healthy children, all of whom are going/went to better schools than I did growing up, live in a better neighborhood than I did growing up, and generally have an easier path towards a successful adult life than I had growing up.

I have a nicer house than my parents had when I was a kid. More disposable income. We take more frequent vacations to nicer places.

Basically, I’m doing better than my parents, and, chances are, my kids will do better than me. That’s my American Dream.

My sister got into drugs at around age 14, was a drug addict from that point on, and died of an overdose when she was 34. She could have had the American Dream, too, but she made some stupid decisions that were beyond the control of my parents, and ruined the Dream herself. As long as my own children don’t make stupid decisions like that, they should have an easy time living their own American Dream.

[Controversial statement ahead.]

For most able-bodied, mentally-sound adults, the American Dream isn’t all that difficult to achieve. People who complain about it are often complaining about the negative effects of their own decisions that they made when they were younger. If, for example, you think that the American Dream is dead because you’re in your late 20s and still can’t afford a house because of student loan debt and a job that doesn’t pay very well… who put you in that position? You’re the one who took out the loans for a degree that didn’t result in a lucrative career.

The majority of people whose complaints about the American Dream being dead I read online fall into one of these three categories:

  • People who have drug habits… a personal lifestyle choice of theirs.
  • People who have “crushing” student loan debt and can’t find lucrative employment… a position they put themselves in.
  • People who struggle to find someone to settle down and raise a family with.

For that last one, I am very thankful that I found my wife fairly early in life and before internet dating was a big deal. For what I’ve read and heard, apps like Tinder have made it much more difficult for people to find someone… particularly women… who is interested in settling down and raising a family.

March 25
Teacher (2009–present)
What is the root problem in US politics?

I’d go with a lack of unifying cultural norms, morals, or expectations from individuals and governments, as well as a lack of any real external threat that may unite such a diverse group of people.

Cultural diversity is great for a lot of things, but it’s not very conducive to “getting things done” if “getting things done” requires agreements among the masses about things that have a moral aspect to them.

Gun control is a good example of this. For some American subcultures, gun ownership is a rite of passage. It’s a past time. It’s a way of life. It’s a symbol of freedom. For some, the threat of a slippery slope towards government oppression beginning with even small gun control measures doesn’t sound crazy. For some, restricting the rights of law-abiding citizens to own any gun they want is immoral.

But, for other American subcultures, guns are evil. They are tools that are only used to commit crimes or kill people. They think that the Founding Fathers could not have possibly understood what innovations there would be in guns in the future. They see no problem with what they term “sensible gun laws.” They don’t worry about a slippery slope into government oppression. Gun ownership isn’t a rite of passage for them.

Until one of those American subcultures becomes the dominant culture, nothing is going to get done when it comes to gun control.

You really have to look at the U.S. more like the E.U. now: an association of different cultures that can agree on some things for their mutual benefit, but where respect for subcultural norms and local laws and customs is paramount.

Abortion and animal rights are good issues to see the different subcultural morals in the United States. There are strict laws in place for protecting animals from abuse and suffering… even animals whose sole purpose in life is to be slaughtered and fed to humans… while some American subcultures push back against any attempt to restrict abortions, although the unborn can feel suffering, too. Both of these issues rely on some sort of shared morality among the masses to be “settled,” and there is no shared morality across the whole or even the majority of the American populace. So these issues… particularly the abortion issue… will never be “settled,” until there isn’t as much moral diversity in the United States.

When was the government less divided and more able to “get things done?” When there was one dominant subculture among the populace, at the same time there was an existential threat to the country. A diverse populace + safety from any existential threat = political gridlock.

Teacher (2009–present)
What did shopping used to be like?

I can answer as to the small-town American shopping experience of the late 1980s-early 1990s.

There’s a great youtube series called “Dead Malls,” where a guy walks around giant indoor malls that are closed or barely hanging on.

When I was a kid, those malls were very much alive, and that’s where we did all of our non-grocery shopping. They had big anchor department stores at the ends of every major wing, plants and fountains in the walkways, plenty of seating areas, a food court, an arcade, and dozens of other shops. Families would go there as a group, then split up and go their separate ways to do their shopping. Boys like me usually ended up at the arcade. Men like my father usually ended up getting a drink and sitting in one of the sitting areas to “people watch.”

They all had a small bookstore, too.

And a small toy store.

And a music store where you could listen to music before buying it on cassette or, if you were rich, CD.

And one or two hair salons. Sometimes one specifically for children.

The better malls also had movie theaters in them.

And dine-in restaurants separate from the cafeteria-like food court.

And mall walkers… old people who did laps around the inside of the mall as exercise.

And, around Christmas, they’d have a Santa in the middle of the mall, for picture-taking purposes.

My mother was a manager of a shoe store in the local mall in my hometown for a while there when I was a kid. Of about 40 stores in that mall, 5 of them were shoe stores.

Parents would often drop their pre-teens off at the mall to “hang out” with their friends for a while. You couldn’t go to the mall in the evening without running into someone you knew from school.

There are a few malls like this that still do good business in the Chicago area. I go to one called Northbrook Court about twice per year, mostly because that’s where the Lego store is. But every time I go there, it gets a little more depressing, as every time there are fewer and fewer other people there.

Outdoor malls seem to be doing better these days, around here at least. The one near me recently became pet-friendly, so people can walk their dogs there, too, and hopefully spend some money.

Wal-Mart and Target were the beginning of the end of the mall in my hometown. Amazon was the final nail in the coffin.

Now that small hometown mall, like many others, has been converted to other uses. They have just a few big stores in them, like hobby or sporting goods stores, and their entrances are to the parking lot, not to the interior of the mall. Basically, they’ve been converted into strip malls.

Teacher (2009–present)
People tell me that school choice will harm minorities, but school choice will allow minorities to get out of the schools that abuse and underteach their children. Why is school choice so bad?

People who are against school choice tend to do three things that people who are for school choice do not:

  1. Assume that a lack of funding is why certain schools do worse than other schools.
  2. Bring race into every single policy debate.
  3. View students as some sort of collective national commodity.

People who are for school choice tend to:

  1. Assume that students’ home lives are the primary factor some schools do worse than others.
  2. Ignore race in policy debates, preferring to bring in “socio-economic status” if some sort of division is necessary.
  3. View students as individuals.

When you look at school choice through the first lens… the anti-choice lens… school choice will both help and harm minorities the most. That’s because school choice only works in places where choices exist (cities), which also happen to be the places where minorities are the largest group that don’t already have a choice via their income levels.

There are more whites living in poverty than minorities living in poverty in the U.S. However, those impoverished whites tend to live in more rural areas without many school options. More urban whites tend to have more income and more choices in schools due to their income levels and where they live.

For example, here are the races of students in the Chicago Public School district:

And here are the income levels of the families of Chicago Public School students:

But here are the races of Chicago citizens:

You will notice that white students are under-represented in Chicago Public Schools compared to the number of white citizens in Chicago. There are only two possibilities:

  1. White people in Chicago don’t have school-aged children, or
  2. White people in Chicago are more likely to send their children to private schools.

That is, white people in Chicago are more likely to already have school choice via their income levels, while minorities are more likely to need government-sponsored school choice to get the same options.

Government-sponsored school choice will mostly help minority students in cities like Chicago, because those are the students most likely to be stuck in a failing school. It will also hurt the students who are left behind… students who are more likely to be minorities, due to the fact that many white students have already left the public school system.

In other words: In Chicago, and other similar major cities in the U.S., ANY school choice program will both help and hurt minority students, because most of the public school students in those places are minorities.

If you stop looking at students as some sort of collective commodity for the country, and start looking at them as individuals who, along with their parents, are capable of making the best decisions for themselves, school choice is the best choice. If some students get left behind… it’s on those students, and their parents, to do what’s in their best interests. It’s not a collective societal problem, but hundreds of thousands of individual problems with hundreds of thousands of individual solutions.

Denying some students a ticket out of a failing school via school choice because it would be detrimental for the students who are left behind is like poking holes in a life raft that doesn’t hold everyone, so the people in the water have more company.

How has the quarantine period affected your relationships?

It made already-awesome relationships even better.

My wife was working from home two days per week before the lockdowns began. Once the lockdown began, her company sent her all new work-from home equipment, including a standing desk and nice office chair. We converted our sun room into her office and installed new climate control in it (it didn’t have AC or heat before). My wife is probably the happiest she’s been, work-wise, for as long as I’ve known her. She loves being home all day. Her happiness, and the extra time we get to spend together, has improved our relationship, which was already doing great beforehand.

My oldest daughter moved back in with us for the first six months of the lockdown. Again, our relationship with her was already great, but having her back home just made it better. It’s nice having a third adult in the house for a while.

I got to spend more time with my younger children, too. I was already spending plenty of time with them, but the added time was nice. My wife and oldest daughter got to spend more time with them, too.

My younger kids also became better friends with the neighborhood kids over the summer. Since all summer camps and sports leagues and whatnot were canceled, parents just did the old-fashioned thing and told their kids to go play outside when it was nice outside. The kids found the other neighborhood kids, and they had a lot of fun together. It was one of those summers that, when they’re adults, they will look back on with fond memories of all of the fun they had just hanging out with the neighborhood kids.

And my dog has never been so spoiled before. I’m not sure if she can go back to having the house to herself for a whole day. My wife… who was “iffy” about getting a dog in the first place… really enjoys having the dog with her while she works from home all day. I enjoy walking the dog more often, just for a little break from everyone in my house.

Everyone in my family just seems to be a lot happier, and that, plus the extra time together, has brought us all closer.

March 23
M.A. in Teaching & English (language), DePaul University (Graduated 2009)
As a teacher, if you could add one thing to the teaching curriculum, what would it be?

Direction reading/step-by-step direction following.

This would solve about 50% of the issues my middle school students face when it comes to their school work. That is, half of all wrong answers would actually have been correct answers if the students had simply read and followed the directions.

Something like this happens almost every day in my class:

Directions: Read each sentence. If the sentence is grammatically correct, write “correct.” If the sentence is incorrect, rewrite it to make it correct.

About a dozen students: [Turn in papers with just “correct” and “incorrect” for answers.]

Each one that they wrote “incorrect” for is automatically wrong, because they didn’t follow the directions. A similar thing happens when the directions say something like “write true or false for each statement, and if false, correct the statement to make it true.” They’ll just turn in a page full of true/false answers, but no corrections for the false ones. So all of those are automatically wrong.

Then the students want partial credit for getting half of the answer correct. I don’t give it to them. I want them to learn from their mistakes and not repeat them. Some do the first time. Some do after a few months. Some never do. They read the first direction in a series of directions, and skip right to the questions. Some don’t even read the first direction. They just assume that they know what to do, or just don’t care.

The permanent first direction for any assignment is to put your name and the date on it. When students turn in nameless papers, I hold it up, ask whose it is, then crumple it up and throw it away, encouraging the student to remember to put their name on it next time. It’s a shock tactic, but it works well with the 11-year-old sixth graders. They usually remember to put their names on their paper from that day forward.

Well, we did it with her and my in-laws and my grown child and future grown children in mind. We’re converting our basement into an in-law apartment. It turns out that finishing an unfinished basement, complete with adding a bathroom, kitchenette, and bedroom, is really expensive. At least here in Chicago. I could build a nice house from scratch next to my mother’s house for less than I’m paying for this in-law apartment in the house I already own.

Anyway, when I was a teen, I once spent a $100 graduation present from my grandfather on some box speakers for my car. They were a total waste of money because my car stereo didn’t have the power to use them properly. I ended up just giving them to a friend when I moved away for college just two months later. I never told my parents about that.

Teacher (2009–present)
How do individuals in society move from one social stratum to the next?

It depends on which direction they’re moving.

Here’s how the people I know who moved up the socio-economic ladder did it:

  1. Marry someone who makes as much or more than you. Your combined incomes and shared expenses take you up a rung or two. It also helps if you live a modest lifestyle.
  2. Start a business providing goods or services to wealthy people. The first millionaire I ever had a conversation with was a speech therapist who had her own business in Chicago’s wealthy northern suburbs. She worked with disabled children whose parents (or their insurance) would pay $100–200 per hour for her services. Well, her business’s services. She hired other therapists to do most of the actual therapy. I also know people who’ve done similar things with a tutoring business in the affluent suburbs, and home improvement in the wealthy suburbs. If you’re going to start a business, do it where people have the most disposable income.
  3. Become a doctor, lawyer, or someone who knows how to work with hi-tech machinery. This is the path up the rungs that schools push the most, but, honestly, I, personally, only know a few people who took this path to move up some rungs. Most people I know who took this path were already born pretty high up the ladder in the first place.
  4. Work for the local government of a major “blue” city. Chicago, for example, pays its civil servants very well. It’s not too difficult for even rookie cops, firefighters, or public school teachers to make six figures a year, if they pick up extra hours or responsibilities.

The people I know who went down some rungs on the socio-economic ladder did it this way:

  1. Do hard drugs. I’m in my 40s, and the people I know who do hard drugs are all either dead by now, or living in poverty. The people who died lived in poverty before they finally overdosed.
  2. Get convicted of a felony. A lot of employers won’t even give you an interview if a felony conviction shows up on your background check.
  3. Have multiple children with someone (or more people) you’re not legally bound to. This applies to both single mothers and fathers who have child support payments. Besides the added expenses of children, there’s also the added responsibilities and lack of flexibility that may make it difficult to work your way up at your job.
