March 20
Teacher (2009–present)
What lie have you told yourself that you now cannot be convinced isn’t true?
Originally Answered: What did you believe was a lie that you now believe is true?

Not a full lie, but an overused excuse.

Before becoming a teacher, I thought behavioral disorders in students (attention deficit, hyperactivity, oppositional defiance, etc…) were really rare and most students who were diagnosed with those disorders didn’t really have them, but just suffered from poor parenting and a lack of consequences. I thought that, for example, if a student kept interrupting the teacher, it was because the student never got any consequences for it at home. Or, if a student couldn’t focus on a lecture for more than a few seconds, they just needed to try harder.

It wasn’t until I became a teacher myself that I realized that these conditions are not only real, but much more common than I thought. I went from “what kind of overly-permissive parenting has led this child to the age of 12 and still interrupting their teacher” to “oh my God, this child seriously doesn’t even realize that they’re talking right now, while I’m trying to teach. They are completely oblivious to the sound of their own voice.”

I call them “hardwiring issues” now, rather than “upbringing issues.” It may have a little to do with how they were raised, or their upbringing certainly didn’t help matters, but it’s more like a physical problem in their minds over which they have little to no control.

Getting mad at the student who won’t stop talking while you’re trying to teach may be like getting mad at the blind kid because they can’t see what you’ve written on the board. It’s not their fault, even if it makes your job as a teacher that much more complicated.

Sounds interesting and promising. What was different about their approach to teaching?

Lewis EdgeWith my son, the school did not label him and make him feel different by shuttling him to a “resource room.” Using proven military systems of predictable rewards and punishments with a strong emphasis on encouragement and individual attention the students could not simply blow off their homework. If a student failed to do his homework, for example, he would immediately be assigned to a supervised evening study hall. Ultimately students came to understand that failing to perform academically was simply not an option. When students worked hard and succeeded, they were paraded in front of the entire student body to be recognized and honored. That was a strong positive motivation. If students resisted the program they would be required to devote every evening and weekend to academic work instead of enjoying recreation and off campus activities. One evening I received a phone call from a concerned parent seeking my advice. They told me that that after two weeks their son hated the school and had threatened to commit suicide if they did not take him out. After our discussion I asked them to let me bring up their concerns with the school commandant who would appropriately deal with their son’s threat. The threat was handled. A couple of months later during the parents’ first meeting with their son after his enrollment and “basic orientation,” he had been positively transformed so completely that his parents initially did not recognize him. I had observed similar transformations during my military basic training after I joined the Air Force after college.

How is COVID-19 affecting teachers, both off work and at work?

I can only speak for myself on this one.

It’s been mostly positive for me, but I’m also the type of guy who always looks for the positive in any situation.

The private school district for which I teach has been doing in-person learning all year, while the local public school district has not. This has resulted in a wave of new students for us, which is nice. About 10% of the students I teach this year transferred here over the summer from a public school that wasn’t opening for in-person learning at the beginning of the year. I’m happy for my students who have a larger pool of potential school friends now. I’m also happy for the school, because each new student brings with them more resources (tuition). The majority of new students this year also happen to be the types of students teachers love: highly motivated, respectful, and kind to their classmates.

My students’ parents have been extremely appreciative of what the teachers and the school have been doing to make in-person learning possible this year. The official parent organization for the school has shown their appreciation for us by organizing drives to make sure the teachers’ lounge is always stocked with food, collecting money for Christmas bonuses for the teachers, and generally making us feel like we’re appreciated.

The students are also very appreciative of being back in school. They liked e-learning for about two weeks, when they thought it was just a long break. But, by about a month into it, they hated it. They were happy to see their friends again. As an added bonus, the COVID measures double as good behavior measures. Keeping students socially distanced and with masks on cuts down on the side conversations a lot.

Keeping students in the same room all day (a cohort), as opposed to having them move from room to room throughout the day, also adds more time to the classes. We did this so that if one student caught COVID, just that class had to quarantine, not the whole school. Teachers don’t stop to chat as they move from room to room. Transitions between classes used to be 10-minute ordeals. Now they’re like 30 seconds. When this is all over and things are back to “normal,” that’s what I’m going to miss most: all of the time we saved by keeping students in one spot all day.

We also get to watch movies during lunch now, to keep the students from talking to each other when their masks are off. Students eat in their classroom, instead of the cafeteria, to keep the cohorts from mixing. I let my students pick the movies to watch, and for the last month, we’ve been working our way through the entire Star Wars series. We’re on “Rogue One” now. We’re watching them in story order.

All of our precautions have worked perfectly so far. There has not been a single instance of in-school transmission of COVID this year. Some students have come down with COVID after having sleepovers or parties with friends they have outside of school, and that caused some of our cohorts to quarantine for two weeks, but the school can’t control what parents allow their children to do outside of school.

The only negatives I can think of from teaching during this COVID year are:

  • I cannot arrange my classroom the way I want to. Desks have to be spread out, and that leaves only one good way to arrange them so all students can see the board.
  • Student 1:1 tech has been hard to come by. My students already had 1:1 tech, but the new students took the spares, and new spares are on back order all over the country. If a student’s Chromebook goes down during the day, it adds complications for the teacher. In previous years, we’d just give them a spare and move on.
  • To avoid crowds of students outside of the school before and after school, every student had a designated arrival and departure time, spread out over 30 minutes. It’s just an annoying complication when planning what to do every day.
  • The “specials” teachers who don’t have homerooms (art, music, Spanish, gym, etc…) had to become cart-based teachers this year. Since the students can’t go to their rooms, they put everything on a cart and go to the students’ rooms. This sucked for all of them, but especially the art teacher. She has multiple carts full of art supplies that she has to schlep around now, and her perfect art room sits unused.

What is the “act like every gun you handle is loaded” of your profession?

In teaching, it’s:

  • Never be alone with a student.
  • Never leave students alone.
  • Document everything, especially discipline issues.

All three of which are versions of “protect yourself from false allegations and lawsuits.”

If you’re alone with a student, even for a few minutes, and that student says that you did something inappropriate, you can lose your job. Even if there is no evidence, just that student’s word is enough to get many teachers fired and their reputations ruined.

When dropped off at school in the morning, parents assume that their children will be under the supervision of an employee of the school at all times during the day. If you’re teaching a class and you need to leave the room, you have to get another adult employee of the school to monitor your students while you’re gone. If you leave students unsupervised and something happens to one of them, it’s your fault. You will lose your job and your reputation, and the school may be sued.

Documenting everything, especially discipline issues, is about covering your ass when it comes time to give out bad grades or move up the discipline ladder. You can’t go from “0” to “your kid has failed my class” or “your kid is suspended.” You have to show that parents were warned multiple times, every step of the way, of how bad things were getting with their child. Otherwise, you open yourself up to discrimination lawsuits, among other things.

“You only failed/suspended my child because they’re [race/gender/ethnicity/socio-economic status/special needs status/religion/etc…].”

Yes, there are parents who will say that, and threaten lawsuits because of it. Hence the need for constant documentation, to show that it’s not just because the teacher doesn’t like the student for whatever reason.
